Title: Health Care Facilities - Service Member Community Members (SFC Matthew Fast Act )
Synopsis: Authorizing each health care facility to screen each patient for information on whether the patient is a service member community member, include on the patient's medical record whether the patient is a service member community member, and  meet certain standards established by The Joint Commission for the purpose of improving health care equity for warrior community members; and defining "service member community member" to mean a service member, a veteran, a certain spouse, a certain child, or a certain stepchild.
bill_summary: The bill requires health care facilities in Maryland to screen patients for their status as service members or veterans and include this information in medical records. It aims to improve health care equity for service members, veterans, and their families by identifying them as a vulnerable population and reporting on progress annually.
responsible_party: Department of Veterans and Military Families
stakeholders: Service members, veterans, their families, and health care providers in Maryland
access_to_capital_summary: The bill primarily focuses on health care equity and does not directly impact access to capital for small business owners.

Title: Condominiums and Homeowners Associations - Elections, Financial Statements, and Enforcement
Synopsis: Establishing certain requirements for elections of the governing body of a condominium or homeowners association; requiring that the governing body of a condominium accommodate unit owner organizing activities relating to the governance of the condominium; prohibiting unit owners and lot owners from being charged for examining certain records of the condominium or homeowners association in a certain manner; etc.
bill_summary: The bill establishes requirements for elections, records access, and enforcement for condominiums and homeowners associations in Maryland. It aims to improve transparency, fairness, and accountability in governance and record-keeping.
responsible_party: Division of Consumer Protection of the Office of the Attorney General
stakeholders: Unit owners, lot owners, condominium and homeowners association members in Maryland
access_to_capital_summary: The bill primarily focuses on governance and record access, with no direct provisions affecting access to capital for small business owners.

Title: Calvert County Sheriff - Deputy Sheriffs and Correctional Deputies - Collective Bargaining
Synopsis: Providing that full-time deputy sheriffs and correctional deputies at the rank of major and below in the Calvert County Sheriff's Office have the right to organize and negotiate with the County Administrator of Calvert County and the Calvert County Sheriff with regard to certain wages and employee benefits in a certain manner.
bill_summary: The bill grants certain deputy sheriffs and correctional deputies in Calvert County the right to organize and negotiate with county authorities regarding wages and employee health care premium share, establishing a process for collective bargaining and certification of labor organizations.
responsible_party: Calvert County Sheriffโs Office and Calvert County government
stakeholders: Deputy sheriffs and correctional deputies in Calvert County, county government, and residents of Calvert County
access_to_capital_summary: The bill's impact on access to capital is indirect, primarily through improved labor relations and negotiations for wages and benefits.

Title: Health Benefit Plans - Calculation of Cost-Sharing Contribution - Requirements
Synopsis: Requiring administrators, carriers, and pharmacy benefits managers to include certain cost sharing amounts paid by or on behalf of an enrollee or a beneficiary when calculating the enrollee's or beneficiary's contribution to a cost sharing requirement for certain health care services; providing that the calculation requirement does not apply to enrollees in certain high-deductible health plans; requiring third parties that pay certain financial assistance to provide certain notification to an enrollee; etc.
bill_summary: The bill requires health insurers, nonprofit health plans, and health maintenance organizations to include discounts, financial assistance, and out-of-pocket expenses when calculating cost-sharing contributions for prescription drugs. It also mandates notification to enrollees about financial assistance and prohibits coverage terms from being conditioned on the availability of such assistance. The law aims to improve transparency and prevent double-dipping in cost-sharing calculations.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Insurance
stakeholders: Insured individuals, enrollees, health insurers, nonprofit health plans, health maintenance organizations, pharmacy benefits managers, and third-party financial assistance providers in Maryland.
access_to_capital_summary: The program has a high potential to impact small business owners by increasing transparency and fairness in prescription drug cost-sharing, which can influence the availability and terms of financial assistance programs.

Title: Annual Corrective Bill
Synopsis: Correcting certain errors or omissions in certain articles of the Annotated Code; clarifying language; correcting certain obsolete references; reorganizing certain sections of the Annotated Code; providing that the Act is not intended to affect any law other than to correct technical errors; and providing for the correction of certain errors and obsolete provisions by the publishers of the Annotated Code.
bill_summary: This bill is an annual correction bill that amends various sections of Maryland law to fix errors, update references, and clarify language across multiple articles, including those related to health, education, environment, and public safety.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Legislative Services
stakeholders: Maryland residents, government agencies, and organizations affected by the legal corrections
access_to_capital_summary: This bill does not directly impact small business access to capital, as it mainly corrects legal and technical errors in existing laws.

Title: Labor and Employment - Unpaid Parental Leave - Definition of Employer
Synopsis: Altering the definition of "employer" to exclude employers who are covered by the federal Family and Medical Leave Act for the current year from being required to provide to employees a certain unpaid parental leave benefit in the State.
bill_summary: The bill amends Maryland law to exclude employers covered by the federal Family and Medical Leave Act from being required to provide unpaid parental leave benefits to employees.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Labor or relevant state agency
stakeholders: Employers with 15 to 49 employees in Maryland and their employees
access_to_capital_summary: The bill does not directly impact access to capital for small business owners.

Title: Higher Education - Hunger-Free Campus Grant Program - Alterations
Synopsis: Requiring the Maryland Higher Education Commission to designate certain private institutions of higher education as hunger-free campuses; prohibiting a 4-year or 2-year private institution of higher education or a regional higher education center operated by a private nonprofit institution of higher education from being eligible to receive grant funding under the Hunger-Free Campus Grant Program; and authorizing the Governor in certain fiscal years to include $150,000 in the annual budget bill for the Program.
bill_summary: The bill establishes the HungerโFree Campus Grant Program in Maryland, designates certain campuses as hungerโfree if they meet specific criteria, and allocates funding to support initiatives that address student food insecurity.
responsible_party: Maryland Higher Education Commission
stakeholders: Students at higher education institutions in Maryland, especially those facing food insecurity
access_to_capital_summary: The program has a high potential to improve access to food resources and support services for students, which can indirectly enhance their ability to access capital by reducing financial hardship.

Title: Howard Community College - Board of Trustees, Meetings, and Contracts - Alterations Ho. Co. 1-25
Synopsis: Adding two members to the Board of Community College Trustees for Howard County; requiring each meeting of the Board to allow for public comment; requiring the Board to make a video or audio recording of its meetings which are to be made available on the Board's website; requiring Board members to undergo certain training specific to Board governance; and requiring the Board to submit a report to the General Assembly by January 1, 2026, and every 6 months thereafter until a contract is finalized, on the status of the faculty union contract.
bill_summary: This bill modifies the governance and oversight of Howard Community College, including increasing the number of trustees, establishing meeting and transparency requirements, mandating biennial training for trustees, and setting procedures for contract renewal and public feedback.
responsible_party: Howard Community College Board of Trustees
stakeholders: Employees, students, and residents of Howard County
access_to_capital_summary: The bill's provisions are mainly governance and transparency measures, with no direct funding or financial programs impacting access to capital.

Title: Municipalities - Enforcement of Ordinances and Resolutions
Synopsis: Increasing from $1,000 to $5,000 the maximum amount of a criminal fine or municipal infraction that may be imposed by a municipality to enforce certain ordinances and resolutions enacted by the municipality.
bill_summary: This bill increases the maximum fines that municipalities in Maryland can impose for violations of ordinances and resolutions, raising the cap from $1,000 to $5,000. It also clarifies that violations can be classified as misdemeanors or municipal infractions, with corresponding penalties.
responsible_party: Municipal governments in Maryland
stakeholders: Residents and businesses within Maryland municipalities, municipal governments, local law enforcement
access_to_capital_summary: The bill does not directly impact access to capital for small business owners.

Title: Workers' Compensation - Claims Application Form - Authorization for Release of Information
Synopsis: Altering the entities to which a claimant is required to authorize the release in a claim application filed with the Workers' Compensation Commission to include the Uninsured Employers' Fund and the Subsequent Injury Fund; altering the information which a claimant is required to authorize the release in a claim application to include additional claims filed by the claimant and information in the custody of the Commission; etc.
bill_summary: The bill amends Maryland's workers' compensation law to specify the entities to which claimants must authorize the release of medical and financial information when filing claims, including claims related to injuries, death, or occupational diseases, and clarifies the scope and duration of these authorizations.
responsible_party: Maryland Workersโ Compensation Commission
stakeholders: Workers filing workers' compensation claims and their employers and insurers
access_to_capital_summary: The bill's provisions are unlikely to have a direct impact on small business owners' access to capital.

Title: Department of Human Services - Study on Private Treatment Foster Care Homes
Synopsis: Requiring the Department of Human Services to conduct a study to determine the types of State support that would be appropriate and beneficial to assist private providers of treatment foster care homes in the provision of services; and requiring the Department to report its findings and recommendations on or before December 1, 2025.
bill_summary: The bill requires the Maryland Department of Human Services to review and reallocate part of its budget to provide child care stipends to private treatment foster care homes, similar to public ones. It also mandates a study to determine the types of state support beneficial for private providers of treatment foster care homes.
responsible_party: Department of Human Services
stakeholders: Private treatment foster care homes, children in foster care, families, and private providers of treatment foster care
access_to_capital_summary: The bill has a high potential to impact access to capital for private treatment foster care providers by providing funding and stipends.

Title: Electronic Smoking Devices - Seizure and Wholesaler Record-Keeping Requirements
Synopsis: Authorizing the Executive Director of the Alcohol, Tobacco, and Cannabis Commission to seize electronic smoking devices that are sold or offered for sale in violation of certain provisions of law without a warrant; establishing procedures for the return of certain property seized by the Executive Director; establishing certain record-keeping requirements for electronic smoking devices wholesaler distributors and wholesaler importers; etc.
bill_summary: The bill authorizes the seizure of illegal tobacco products and electronic smoking devices without a warrant, establishes procedures for handling seized property, and creates licensing and record-keeping requirements for electronic smoking device wholesalers and manufacturers.
responsible_party: Alcohol, Tobacco, and Cannabis Commission of Maryland
stakeholders: Electronic smoking device manufacturers, wholesalers, retailers, and consumers in Maryland
access_to_capital_summary: The bill's provisions on licensing and record-keeping could impact the operational capacity of small businesses involved in electronic smoking devices, potentially affecting their access to capital.

Title: Maryland Self-Service Storage Act - Sale of Personal Property in Satisfaction of Lien - Notice Requirements
Synopsis: Requiring an operator of a certain self-service storage facility to notify an occupant in default at least 10 days before conducting a sale of the occupant's property stored in the self-storage facility of the time, place, and terms of the sale by hand delivery, verified mail, or electronic mail at the occupant's last known address; and requiring the operator of a self-storage facility to send a second notice if no response has been received 5 days prior to the sale.
bill_summary: This bill updates the Maryland SelfโService Storage Act to specify notification requirements for operators before selling a tenantโs stored personal property due to default, including rules for electronic notices and advertising of sales.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Commerce or relevant selfโservice storage regulatory authority
stakeholders: Selfโservice storage facility operators and tenants in Maryland
access_to_capital_summary: The bill does not directly impact access to capital for small business owners.

Title: Business Regulation - Cellular Phone Carriers - Authorized Users
Synopsis: Requiring a cellular phone carrier to allow a customer of record who is responsible for payment of an account to have the option to designate other individuals as authorized users on the customer's account and to allow an authorized user to take certain actions in connection with the account.
bill_summary: The bill requires cellular phone carriers in Maryland to include an option in their service contracts that allows multiple individuals to be designated as authorized users on an account. These authorized users can then purchase services, devices, or take actions related to the account, provided all record customers agree in writing.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Commerce or relevant cellular phone carriers
stakeholders: Cellular phone customers, especially those who want to authorize others to manage their accounts
access_to_capital_summary: The bill potentially improves access to services and account management for small business owners and individuals by allowing authorized users to act on accounts, which could facilitate business operations.

Title: Mold - Landlord Requirements and Regulations (Maryland Tenant Mold Protection Act)
Synopsis: Requiring the Department of the Environment, the Maryland Department of Health, the Department of Housing and Community Development, the Maryland Department of Labor, and the Department of General Services to develop a certain pamphlet and website; requiring a landlord to provide a tenant with certain information at certain times and in a certain manner; requiring a landlord to perform a mold assessment and mold remediation within 15 days after receipt of a written notice regarding the detection of mold; etc.
bill_summary: The bill establishes regulations and standards for mold assessment and remediation in Maryland, including requirements for landlords to provide information to tenants, perform mold assessments, and remediate mold issues within specific timeframes. It also mandates the development of informational resources and the adoption of uniform standards for mold management.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of the Environment, Maryland Department of Health, Department of Housing and Community Development, Maryland Department of Labor, Department of General Services
stakeholders: Tenants, landlords, property owners, and residents in Maryland
access_to_capital_summary: The bill's focus on mold assessment and remediation standards may indirectly impact small business owners involved in mold remediation services, but it primarily sets regulatory standards rather than providing direct financial support or capital access programs.

Title: Cyber Maryland Program - Revisions
Synopsis: Transferring the Cyber Maryland Program from the Maryland Technology Development Corporation to the Maryland Department of Labor; altering the duties of the Program; requiring the Program to issue competitive grants and contracts beginning in fiscal year 2026, to enhance cybersecurity workforce development, including cybersecurity for operational technology; authorizing the Governor for fiscal year 2027 and each fiscal year thereafter to include in the annual budget bill an appropriation sufficient to run the program; etc.
bill_summary: The bill revises the Cyber Maryland Program, transferring it to the Maryland Department of Labor, expanding its duties, establishing a funding structure, and creating a governing board. It aims to develop cybersecurity workforce talent, support related programs, and improve cybersecurity infrastructure in Maryland.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Labor
stakeholders: Cybersecurity workforce, educational institutions, employers, veterans, and cybersecurity program participants in Maryland.
access_to_capital_summary: The bill has a high potential to impact small business owners' access to capital by funding cybersecurity clinics, workforce training, and industry attraction campaigns.

Title: Department of the Environment - Community Water and Sewerage Systems - Cybersecurity Planning and Assessments
Synopsis: Requiring the Department of the Environment to coordinate, in coordination with the Department of Information Technology and the Maryland Department of Emergency Management, cybersecurity efforts within community water systems and community sewerage systems; establishing the roles and responsibilities of various State agencies with respect to regulating, assessing, and promoting cybersecurity efforts within the water and wastewater sector; etc.
bill_summary: This bill mandates the Maryland Department of the Environment to coordinate cybersecurity efforts for community water and sewerage systems, establish standards, require incident reporting, and promote cybersecurity awareness and training within the water sector.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of the Environment, Department of Information Technology, Maryland Department of Emergency Management
stakeholders: Community water and sewerage system providers, local governments, and residents served by these systems in Maryland.
access_to_capital_summary: The program's focus on cybersecurity standards, incident reporting, and training could improve the security and resilience of water infrastructure, potentially reducing risks that could impact access to reliable water services.

Title: Governor's Office for Children - Boys and Girls Clubs of Maryland - Grant Funding
Synopsis: Requiring the Governor to include $250,000 in the annual budget bill for fiscal years 2027 through 2030 to the Governor's Office for Children to provide grants to fund operating expenses for the Boys and Girls Clubs of Maryland.
bill_summary: The bill requires the Maryland governor to include a $250,000 annual appropriation from fiscal year 2027 through 2030 in the state budget to fund grants for the Boys and Girls Clubs of Maryland, as part of the efforts of the Governor's Office for Children.
responsible_party: Governorโs Office for Children
stakeholders: Children and families served by the Boys and Girls Clubs of Maryland
access_to_capital_summary: The bill allocates specific funding for grants to the Boys and Girls Clubs, which could improve their access to capital for operational expenses.

Title: Office of Social Equity - Community Reinvestment and Repair Fund - Modifications
Synopsis: Repealing provisions of law requiring the Office of Social Equity to report on the Community Reinvestment and Repair Fund and to solicit public input on the uses of the Fund and publish a review of the input; requiring the Office to oversee the appropriation of funds from the Fund and to train Fund recipients; altering certain limitations on the use of the Fund; limiting certain administrative costs to administer the Fund to a certain amount; requiring counties to administer funds from the Fund in a certain manner; etc.
bill_summary: This bill establishes the Office of Social Equity within the Maryland Cannabis Administration, creates the Community Reinvestment and Repair Fund to support communities impacted by cannabis law enforcement, and sets up a Community Reinvestment and Repair Advisory Board to oversee fund distribution and use. It details program administration, funding sources, eligible uses, and reporting requirements.
responsible_party: Office of Social Equity within the Maryland Cannabis Administration
stakeholders: Communities disproportionately impacted by cannabis law enforcement, community-based organizations, local governments, and residents of Maryland
access_to_capital_summary: The bill allocates funds and resources aimed at supporting community development, health, education, and economic programs, which can improve access to capital for small businesses and community organizations.

Title: Environment - Packaging and Paper Products - Producer Responsibility Plans
Synopsis: Requiring certain producers of covered materials, individually or as part of a producer responsibility organization, to submit a certain covered materials producer responsibility plan to the Department of the Environment for review and approval on or before July 1, 2028, and every 5 years thereafter, in accordance with certain requirements, or to develop an alternative collection program; requiring a producer responsibility organization to pay certain costs to the Department; etc.
bill_summary: The bill establishes a producer responsibility program for packaging materials and paper products in Maryland, requiring producers to submit plans for recycling, reuse, and waste reduction, and creating a framework for funding, oversight, and stakeholder involvement.
responsible_party: Department of the Environment
stakeholders: Producers, local governments, service providers, and residents in Maryland
access_to_capital_summary: The program's structure for funding and infrastructure investment has the potential to improve recycling and reuse systems, which could enhance access to capital for recycling-related businesses and initiatives.

Title: Public Schools - High School Sports Officials - Payment and Fees
Synopsis: Establishing requirements for local school systems that issue invitations for bids for high school sports officiating services for boys' and girls' high school sports; authorizing the Department of Education to develop guidelines to assist a local school system in the implementation of the provisions of the Act, including additional criteria for determining which high school sports qualify as similar boys' and girls' high school sports.
bill_summary: This bill requires Maryland local school systems to issue joint bids for boys' and girls' high school sports officiating services, ensure equal pay for officials in similar roles for similar sports, and develop a list categorizing similar sports for boys and girls. It also sets guidelines for procurement and pay parity, and establishes a process for updating sport categories every three years.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Education in consultation with the Maryland Public Secondary Schools Athletic Association
stakeholders: High school sports officials, school athletic departments, students participating in high school sports, and local school systems
access_to_capital_summary: The bill has the potential to improve pay parity and streamline procurement processes for high school sports officials, which could positively impact officials' access to fair compensation.

Title: Health Insurance - Medicare Supplement Policies - Insurance Producer Commission
Synopsis: Requiring a carrier to pay the same commission rates to an insurance producer for the sale of certain Medicare supplement policies without regard to whether the policies are sold during an open enrollment period, as underwritten policies, or under certain provisions of law.
bill_summary: The bill requires Maryland health insurance carriers to pay the same commission rates to insurance producers for selling Medicare supplement policies, regardless of whether the policies are sold during a guaranteed issue period, open enrollment, or underwritten.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Insurance
stakeholders: Insurance producers, Medicare beneficiaries, health insurance carriers in Maryland
access_to_capital_summary: The bill could potentially improve access to capital for insurance producers by ensuring consistent commission rates, which may encourage more sales and stability.

Title: Municipalities - Legislative Audit - Exemption
Synopsis: Exempting a municipality with annual revenues below $100,000 from a certain audit requirement; clarifying that a certain audit exemption does not affect certain financial reporting requirements; and authorizing the Joint Audit and Evaluation Committee to request or require certain municipalities to conduct a review or audit of their financial records if the financial report indicates a financial or accounting irregularity or concern.
bill_summary: The bill exempts municipalities in Maryland with annual revenues below $100,000 from mandatory financial audits, clarifies that this exemption does not affect financial reporting requirements, and allows the Joint Audit and Evaluation Committee to request or require audits if irregularities are found.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Legislative Services and the Joint Audit and Evaluation Committee
stakeholders: Municipalities with low revenue, local government officials, Maryland residents
access_to_capital_summary: The bill's impact on access to capital is minimal as it mainly changes audit requirements for small municipalities and does not directly address capital access.

Title: Howard County - Patuxent River Wildland - Use of Mechanical or Motorized Equipment Ho. Co. 5-25
Synopsis: Authorizing the Department of Natural Resources to use mechanical or motorized equipment to retain, maintain, remove, or replace existing trails and remove, replace, or dispose of nonnative species within the Patuxent River Wildland to ensure clear and safe access to the wildland.
bill_summary: This bill authorizes the Maryland Department of Natural Resources to use mechanical or motorized equipment within the Patuxent River Wildland for maintenance, ecological preservation, and public education purposes, including maintaining paths and removing nonnative species.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Natural Resources
stakeholders: Public, environmental conservation groups, local communities, and visitors to the Patuxent River Wildland
access_to_capital_summary: The bill's focus on ecological and maintenance activities does not directly impact small business access to capital.

Title: Anne Arundel County - Board of License Commissioners - Alterations
Synopsis: Increasing from three to five the membership of the Board of License Commissioners for Anne Arundel County; altering the eligibility requirements for Board membership; requiring the Board to adopt and publish a certain ethics policy; prohibiting the Board from using certain information as a factor in determining whether to issue or renew a license; requiring the Board to submit a report on the racial breakdown of the disciplinary actions taken by the Board to the General Assembly each year; etc.
bill_summary: The bill makes changes to the Board of License Commissioners for Anne Arundel County, including increasing its membership to five, updating appointment procedures, requiring an ethics policy, and modifying reporting and penalty rules.
responsible_party: Board of License Commissioners for Anne Arundel County
stakeholders: Residents and businesses in Anne Arundel County, license applicants, and licensees
access_to_capital_summary: The bill does not directly impact access to capital for small business owners.

Title: Local Government - Accommodations Intermediaries - Hotel Rental Tax - Collection by Comptroller and Alterations
Synopsis: Requiring certain accommodations intermediaries to collect and remit the hotel rental tax to the Comptroller rather than to each county; providing for the administration of the hotel rental tax by the Comptroller; providing that certain provisions of State law prevail over certain local laws or agreements related to the hotel rental tax; repealing the authority of certain counties to provide for certain exemptions from the hotel rental tax; etc.
bill_summary: The bill mandates that accommodations intermediaries, such as booking platforms, collect and remit hotel rental taxes directly to the Maryland Comptroller instead of local counties, and makes various adjustments to hotel tax laws and procedures across multiple counties and municipalities.
responsible_party: Maryland Comptroller's Office
stakeholders: Hotel guests, hotel and accommodation providers, booking platforms, local governments, and residents in counties and municipalities with hotel taxes.
access_to_capital_summary: The bill's impact on access to capital is indirect, primarily through regulatory changes affecting accommodation and booking platforms, with no direct intervention or funding for capital access.

Title: Natural Resources - Maryland Heritage Areas Authority - Funding and Grants
Synopsis: Authorizing the Maryland Heritage Areas Authority to award grants and loans to certain entities for the management of certified heritage areas under certain circumstances; establishing a maximum funding amount of $300,000 for certain grants, not to exceed 80% of the estimated project cost; decreasing from 10% to 7%, or $600,000, whichever amount is greater, the percentage of Program Open Space funds transferred to the Maryland Heritage Areas Authority Financing Fund that may be used for certain operating expenses; etc.
bill_summary: The bill authorizes the Maryland Heritage Areas Authority to award grants and loans for managing, developing, and revitalizing heritage areas, establishes funding rules, and modifies the use of Program Open Space funds for heritage programs.
responsible_party: Maryland Heritage Areas Authority
stakeholders: Heritage area communities, local governments, and cultural preservation organizations in Maryland
access_to_capital_summary: The bill has a high potential to improve access to capital for heritage area projects, which can indirectly benefit small businesses involved in tourism, preservation, and local development.

Title: Baltimore City - Alcoholic Beverages - License Extension
Synopsis: Extending until the end of July 1, 2026, the expiration of an alcoholic beverages license issued for the 5700 block of Falls Road in Baltimore City for transfer and renewal purposes.
bill_summary: The bill extends the expiration date of a specific alcoholic beverages license in Baltimore City until July 1, 2026, to allow for transfer and renewal purposes.
responsible_party: Baltimore City Alcoholic Beverages Licensing Authority
stakeholders: Alcoholic beverage license holders and businesses in Baltimore City
access_to_capital_summary: The bill does not directly impact access to capital for small business owners.

Title: Baltimore County and Baltimore City - Vehicle Laws - Lighting on Privately Owned Vehicles
Synopsis: Authorizing not more than five of the highest ranking officers from certain nonprofit volunteer emergency medical services organizations located in Baltimore County and Baltimore City to have their privately owned vehicles equipped with red or red and white lights or signal devices which may be displayed only while on route to or at the scene of an emergency.
bill_summary: The bill authorizes certain volunteer emergency medical services organizations in Baltimore County and Baltimore City to allow their top officers to equip their privately owned vehicles with specific red or red and white lights or signal devices, which can only be displayed while on emergency routes or at scenes.
responsible_party: Maryland Department of Transportation or relevant local authorities
stakeholders: Volunteer emergency medical services officers and organizations in Baltimore County and Baltimore City
access_to_capital_summary: The program has a moderate potential to impact access to capital for small business owners, as it involves vehicle equipment modifications for volunteer emergency personnel.

Title: Alcoholic Beverages - Class 5 Breweries - On-Premises Consumption
Synopsis: Increasing the percentage of beer not produced by the holder of a Class 5 brewery license that the license holder is permitted to sell for on-premises consumption if the holder also holds an applicable on-site consumption permit or a Class D license.
bill_summary: The bill increases the percentage of beer not produced by a Class 5 brewery license holder that can be sold for on-premises consumption, allowing more flexibility in the types of beer that can be sold at breweries.
responsible_party: Maryland Alcoholic Beverages and Cannabis Commission
stakeholders: Class 5 brewery license holders, consumers at breweries, beer producers
access_to_capital_summary: The bill does not directly impact access to capital for small business owners.
